posts.name: David
posts.cooked: An Arduino-based controller was developed for two motors using an PWM signal. The controller includes synchronized or independent motor control, a 16x2 LCD screen displaying % output, and four switches for mode selection and motor activation. The hardware comprises an Arduino Uno/Reno, two Potentiometers, two Switches, a Bump Switch, and a Capsule Box. This solution simplifies radio operation, enabling real-time motor control without requiring RC or RoboRIO. Applications include testing radio systems, teaching motor control, and creating custom ESC behaviors.

link_counts.title: FRC Driver Station App for Android

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: This is very cool, I wonder if doing something like an old school brushed motor runner drill conversion would be viable for this, using the grip and trigger form factor and drill batteries is so convenient.

posts.name: David
posts.cooked: The issue with using drill batteries for this purpose is that they likely won’t work unless your batteries can supply a high amount of current. In our design, the Arduino only sends the control signal to the motor, while the actual power comes from an official battery—the same type that every FIRST Robotics Competition team already uses. That said, I might give it a try in the next few days just to see how it behaves.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: If one of our drill batteries can run three CIMS at once at 5400 RPM, it can run one KRACKEN easily.

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked:
Important note: Do not include anything besides the cleaned version. Just the cleaned paragraph.

You run the risk of overdischarging your tool battery, damaging it, and creating a potential safety hazard. This occurs because most tool battery brands incorporate overdischarge protection in the tool itself rather than the battery. Additionally, using a tool battery can expose you to overheating, fire, and even explosion risks due to the inability of power tool batteries to handle the Kraken X60. Considering the current pricing disparity (~$40 for a genuine FRC FIRST Robotics Competition battery versus ~$100 for a tool battery), it’s advisable to opt for the FRC 18Ah SLA battery instead.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Most battery tools are built down to a price, so all the components are just enough to handle the use-case presented by the tool, with very little margin. I have seen conversions like this work for a long time. I have also seen some that work for a short time and then stop working, most likely due to being overloaded. YMMV.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
An important point to consider: Ensure your power-up sequence does not immediately activate the motors. Consider including a warning message such as “not zeroed” during startup.

I have consistently appreciated the control aspect of the power drill's trigger and reverse lever/button.

Slides and knobs are effective for rotation but pose challenges when used for arm, swing, or climbing applications.

I achieved reliable results with a NEO powered by a brushless drill for testing purposes. Additionally, this setup offers the advantage of built-in battery protection.

Power tool brands vary in how they incorporate protection—some into the tool itself, others into the battery. The former often complicates assembly for projects involving multiple power tools.

Testing Kraken mechanisms - #16 by Weldingrod1
